content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" and imposes limitations on the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. The Act in the District of Columbia regulates building heights based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. Section 5-405(h) is amended to allow for the construction of non-occupiable roof structures above prescribed limits if approved by the Mayor, with the condition that they be fireproof and set back from the building's walls at a distance equal to their height above the adjacent roof. The Mayor cannot waive this requirement without approval.
